node.title: It Was One Sign After Another
node.description: When Molly Abrams and Marcus Moss first started dating, they broke up within months. Then she saw a sign that led them to reconnect.
node.content: ["Four months after Molly Abrams and Marcus Moss started dating in 2015, they broke up.", "Introduced by mutual friends, Mr. Moss, 35, said he met the description of the type of guy Ms. Abrams had said she was looking for. \u201cJewish, tall, family oriented, funny, red hair, big dog, name that starts with an M \u2014 basically me,\u201d he said.", "But the two ultimately decided that the distance between them back then \u2014 she was living in Austin, Texas, and he in Memphis \u2014 made a relationship untenable. Ms. Abrams said the decision left her \u201cheartbroken\u201d and that, aside from him sending her a few Instagram posts, there \u201cwasn\u2019t much communication\u201d after the split.", "Then, in 2018, she saw a sign that sparked them to reconnect.", "That fall, Ms. Abrams, 32, noticed that the letter board sign outside of El Arroyo, a restaurant in Austin known for featuring witty phrases on its sign, read \u201cI hope my ex\u2019s dog is doing well.\u201d She took a photograph and posted it on Instagram.", "Mr. Moss, 35, saw it and sent her a direct message on the app in response. It read, \u201cHe\u2019s doing great. But, how are you?\u201d The message, he added, \u201cwas enough for us to reopen a dialogue and once we started talking again, we quickly realized there was still a deep connection between us.\u201d", "They then began a year of long-distance dating, which culminated with Ms. Abrams moving to Memphis in November 2019. She arrived to find that Mr. Moss had created his own sign, in the style of El Arroyo, and put it in his front yard. \u201cThanks, El Arroyo. She posted your sign and it led her to mine. Welcome home, Molly,\u201d it read. (Their reunion was later covered by Spectrum News Austin.)", "Ms. Abrams, who grew up in Dallas, has a bachelor\u2019s degree in health promotion and a master\u2019s degree in health behavior and health education from the University of Texas at Austin. She works as a senior customer success manager at PandaDoc, a software company.", "[Click here to binge read this week\u2019s featured couples.]", "A native of Memphis, Mr. Moss has a bachelor\u2019s degree in political science from the University of Kansas and a law degree from the Mississippi College School of Law. He works as the marketing director for the Interstate Blood Bank, a group of blood donation centers operated by Grifols, a global health care company.", "Mr. Moss\u2019s initial plan to propose to Ms. Abrams in front of El Arroyo\u2019s sign was thwarted by the pandemic. Instead, he proposed in July 2020, when the couple, along with Ms. Abrams\u2019s parents, went to his parents\u2019 house for a Shabbat dinner.", "\u201cMy decision to propose when I did was purely organic,\u201d Mr. Moss said. But it was not spontaneous, because he had prepared a sign for the occasion, which he stationed in his parents\u2019 backyard. It read, \u201cMolly, will you marry me?\u201d", "On Nov. 14, the couple were wed in Memphis, where they live, at Baron Hirsch Congregation, the synagogue Mr. Moss grew up attending. Rabbi Benjamin Lehrfield, formerly of Baron Hirsch and now the rabbi at the Riverdale Minyan in the Bronx, officiated before 260 guests, all but two of whom were fully vaccinated.", "Following the ceremony, the couple and their guests made their way to a reception held at the synagogue\u2019s social hall, which is named in memory of Mr. Moss\u2019s late aunt Marsi Joan Moss, whom he is also named after.", "A black-tie affair included a tequila shot toast with custom glasses emblazoned with \u201cL\u2019chaim from the Mosses,\u201d a book featuring photos of El Arroyo\u2019s sign for guests to inscribe, an Elvis impersonator, and a fake mirrored cake designed to look like a disco ball.", "\u201cVisually, the wedding was a little more fun,\u201d said Ms. Abrams, who added that the couple didn\u2019t want a \u201ctypical wedding.\u201d", "Mr. Moss also had a special kipa made for the occasion. \u201cMarcus has a man bun so he actually cut a half circle out of a leather kipa to make it fit,\u201d Ms. Abrams said. ", "And, of course, there was a sign that recalled El Arroyo\u2019s as part of the d\u00e9cor. It read, \u201cMolly and Marcus. 11-14-21. #MOSSELTOV.\u201d"]
